key_findings.title: Intense Nighttime Activity
key_findings.description: Peak migration occurred between 2-7 AM with 94% of calls during 2 AM hour being flight calls. 662 nocturnal flight calls detected across 12 species including Graylag Goose (481), Spotted Crake (87), and Common Crane (11).

key_findings.title: Interspecies Call-Response Networks
key_findings.description: Detected 151 unique call-response pairs between species. Strongest interaction: Graylag Goose ↔ Spotted Crake (162 bidirectional exchanges). Crows (Carrion/Hooded) showed coordinated alarm responses (9 pairs).

key_findings.title: Multi-Species Alarm Cascades
key_findings.description: 5 major alarm cascade events detected where 3-4 species responded sequentially to perceived threats within 15 seconds. Most common initiators: Carrion Crow, Graylag Goose, and Spotted Crake.

key_findings.title: Individual Vocal Signatures
key_findings.description: Acoustic analysis identified 3 distinct individuals each for 15 species based on vocal tract characteristics and call timing patterns. Most clear differentiation in Yellowhammer, European Robin, and Eurasian Woodcock.

call_response_network.interspecies_communication: Strong bidirectional communication observed between waterfowl (Graylag Goose, Pink-footed Goose) and wetland species (Spotted Crake, Great Bittern)
call_response_network.crow_coordination: Carrion Crow and Hooded Crow showed coordinated alarm responses with 9 documented call-response pairs

alarm_cascades.description: Multi-species alarm cascades where 3-4 species respond to perceived threats within 15-18 seconds

events.species: Carrion Crow, Hooded Crow, Graylag Goose, Spotted Crake
Spotted Crake, Great Bittern, Water Rail
Great Bittern, Spotted Crake, Water Rail
Graylag Goose, Pink-footed Goose, Common Redpoll
Spotted Crake, Graylag Goose, Common Crane

migration_patterns.night_migration: 94% of early morning calls (2-4 AM) were flight calls, indicating active nocturnal migration
migration_patterns.day_migration: Lower migration rates during midday (11 AM - 2 PM) with only 18-32% migration calls
migration_patterns.description: Clear circadian pattern with intense migration 2-7 AM, minimal activity 11 AM - 9 PM, resuming after 10 PM

individual_recognition.method: Acoustic feature clustering based on vocal tract characteristics, frequency modulation, and temporal patterns
individual_recognition.confidence: High - Each species showed 3 distinct vocal signatures with consistent temporal separation

temporal_patterns.dawn_chorus: Intense vocal activity 4-8 AM with 428 Spotted Crake calls and 675 Graylag Goose calls
temporal_patterns.dusk_activity: Moderate evening activity 6-9 PM, primarily waterfowl
temporal_patterns.description: 24-hour acoustic monitoring revealed distinct temporal niches for different species groups

methodology.verification: Manual verification of rare species and low-confidence detections in Raven Pro
methodology.behavioral_analysis: Custom Python algorithms for flight call classification, call-response detection (30s window), alarm cascade identification (15s multi-species events), and individual recognition (k-means clustering)
methodology.equipment: Autonomous recording units, 48 kHz sampling rate, 48.8 hours continuous recording
